415. Muirhead Isabel (Mrs. W.M.)
This is the story of my life in Oakey.
My father came to Saskatchewan from Perth Co., Ont., near the city of Stratford Ont., to Brandon, Man., he spent a short time there but found it very well, so came on to Moose Jaw, Sask.
Then started land hunting and travelled ninety miles south to what is now known as Oakey.
There he took up a homestead at Pechampton, put up a sod shack, and that fall returned to Ont. to spend the winter there.
In the spring of 1883 he returned west bringing a car load of horses and machinery, household furniture etc.
My mother & I came as far as Edmonton by rail, and then by stage coach to Alameda and were among the first to travel on the stage which made weekly trips for some years carrying passengers & mail.
That spring my father broke up some land and put in a crop.
Then as mother did not at all like the sod shack, he started to build a concrete house.
Ohio in the spring of my life in Oakes.

My father came to Oakes from Perth by boat via the city of Bradford Bay to Brandon.

In 1883, he spent a short time there but found it very wet so came on to Summer smile back.

Then David land farming and homesteaded.

Shortly after went to what is now Blanche's Park.

There he built up a house (a small one) and lived there.

On the spring of 1883 he returned west bringing a car load of goods and many personal worth furniture etc.

My mother came as far as Brandon by rail and then by stage coach to Blanche's Park and were among the first to travel on the stage which made weekly trips for some years.

This is the story of my life in Oshkosh.

My father came to Oshkosh from Perth Co., Ont., near the city of Stratford Ont., to Brandon, Man., he spent a short time there but found it very wet, so came on to Wisconsin Dells. Then started land buying and travelled sixty miles south to what is now known as Alameda. There he bought up a homestead or preemption, just up a sod shack and that fall returned to Ont. to spend the winter there.

In the spring of 1883 he returned west bringing a car load of horses machinery, several field furniture etc.

My mother & I came as far as Wisconsin by rail, and then by stage coach to Alameda and were among the first to travel on the stage which made weekly trips for some years bringing passengers & mail.

That spring my father bought up some land and put in a crop.

Then my mother did not at all like the cold shocks she started to build a concrete house.
This is the story of my life in Oahu.

My father came to Hawaii from Perth, Scotland in the early 1880s. He opened a short time there but found ill-health was too severe on the tropical climate.

Then started land farming and handled cattle on a small scale. What is now Kamehameha Beach.

There he built up a homestead or farmstead.

In the spring of 1883 he returned west bringing a car load of horses and machinery.

January 1st, 1884 came so far as homesteading family and then by boat went to Alameda and were among the first to homestead the place which made weekly trips for some years buying lumber and supplies.

That spring my father bought up some land and put in a orchard.

Then we moved to build a new house where he started to build a new house.
which proved very good, and we were able
to move into Neil City; shortly before my
sister was born on Oct 27th 1883, and as she
was the first white child born in the district
one of her names is Alameda.
Needless to say there were no Dr or nurse attending
at her birth, but three neighbors were there to help,
being so far from a railroad neighbor
helped out in any way possible.
We were at Alameda during the time of
the Rebellion in the Mepistle valley, and
as there were many wandering tribes of
Indians travelling around, our grandparents
in fact were greatly concerned for our safety,
but even though we have had whole tribes
of Indians march through our house, and I
remember one time we were at dinner when
a tribe came in, and one very old Indian
reached across the table a short hand with
an old gentleman we had at dinner
that day and how he did laugh.
I must say we were not harmed in the
least; in fact we found them very friendly.
which proved very good, and we were all
to arrive into it in less than thirty before my
daughter was born on Oct 27th 1883, and so she
was the first white child born in the district
of our own province in Alameda.

Needless to say there were no roads or means of travel
at her birth, but three daughters were there to help.
Young as she was from a railroad passenger car
she fell out in any way possible.

We were at Alameda during the time of
the Rebellion in the Mokelumne valley and
so three were on a wandering through
California (not likely around) our grandmothers
we felt more greatly concerned for our safety
but even though we have had whole bunch
of Indians through our house and I
remember one time we were at dinner when
a tribe came in! And one very old Indian
reached across the table, oh yes! Hand with
an old gentleman we had dinner
that day and how he did laugh.
I cannot say we were well harmed in the
least; in fact we found them very friendly.
and thankful for any favors without fail returned any kindness in some way.

In 1886 in Oct 3 my sister Betty was born and we still had no less neighbors again assisted.

In 1887 the men of the district got busy and hauled logs from the Davis River & built a Church. Money was sent out from relations in the east to buy what lumber doors windows etc were needed, and the building was also used for school purposes for many yrs. It was fairly well equipped with desks, black board etc., and served quite a large community for church & school, neighbors came for mile by ox team to church.

We were only able to hold school in summer as we suffered very severe & sudden storms in winter making it dangerous for children to attend. We also were not able to hold Church in Winter as we did not have a regular minister, and had to depend on
and thankful for any favors I wrote out.

But returned away in some way.

For 1886 in Oct 3 my dear little baby was born,

and as we still had two more children again

awaited.

In 1887 the name of the district got larger.

I heard from the owner, Mr. Smith, and built a

Church. Money was sent out from relatives in

the east to buy what timber doors windows etc.

were needed and the building was also

used for school purposes for many years.

It was fairly well equipped with church

place, pews, etc., and served quite a large

community for church or school purposes.

came for only by train to church.

We were only able to hold school in common

as we afforded very scarce and dear prices

in winter because of dangerous for children

to attend. We also were not able to build

a house in Windsor as we did only have a

regular month, and had to depend on
Students sent out who used to ride horseback all over a large territory, preaching in homes & schools, most of them made their headquarters at our home.

Our teachers were also young students with only grade eight and mostly had no normal training.

In the early 1880s we were greatly troubled with horse thieves who used to cross the border from U.S.A. to steal the valuable Canadian horses, so the Mounted Police were sent out to patrol the border, and they traveled with my parents as we were only ½ a mile from the Alameda Rd.

For entertainment we used to have lots of picnics in summer, baseball was quite a popular game, of which my father was captain for yrs, we children ran races etc but me sure didn't get any pop or ice cream, and I never saw an orange till I was twelve yrs old and sure thought it was wonderful, but we had lots of wild fruit as there was a great
We had a large family living in
Texas, evidently most of them made their
road through at own home.
Our children were also young children with
only grade eight and mostly had no formal
training.

In the early 1880s we were greatly troubled
with Indians, who would cross the
border from U.S.A., to steal the valuable
Canadian horses on the Canadian border.
They
would not be afraid of the border, and they
would deal with any person as we were only a
half from the Alameda Rd.

For much farming we used to have lots of
horses in summer, and fall, we would plant a
potato garden, which my father was captain
for you, our children, and I
were divided up among you, but I was always
your own on our hill. I was always your old
and own horse, it was wonderfully kind, we
had lots of wild family so there was a great
abundance in the early days before the prairie fires destroyed so much of it. Also my Grand Parents sent out barrels of honey apples, also apple butter or jelly.

It was a long drive to Moosejaw only taken when really necessary.

My Father raised pigs raising his grain for that purpose, and both out a load in the fall or brought back supplies, there was a small grocery store near the P.O. where we could get any extras. My Parents kept quite a lot of stock & milked about 10 cows, it was my job after school to get them home and I often had to walk two or three miles, also had to walk 1/2 mile to school but as I got older I learned to ride horse back and there was some times four of us on a quiet old horse but we some times had a spill.

In the winter our neighbors used to get together quite often and have parties dancing debates etc., where there were some real good times spent, also neighbors were great for visiting each other and helping out in various ways.

my Father raised pigs raising hogs in that

a breakfast box supplies there was a small

their own, also had a horse Y and a cart
but as I got older I learned to ride a horse
and there was some times four of us on a
quick old horse but we came twice and a half
in the winter our job was to get together quick
then we'd have hard planning debates etc when
there were some real good times also
very little money spent for buying each other
and helping out in anyway.
Sod houses were mostly used as they were warm & cheap, and as coal had to be hauled thirty miles from what was known as the Hugh Macdonald mine near Birdfoot, a warm house was considered a great benefit.

Many farmers used Oxen, which made the long trips very slow; they proved very good though for breaking the new land & were cheaper than horses, but my father never owned a yoke as they were too slow for him, anyway he brought out two good teams of horses from Ont.

Gardens were not grown very extensively as we got early frosts, making it hard to grow even tomatoes & onions, but we always had plenty of root vegetables.

Most farmers had small crops only about 40 or 50 acres as markets were too far away.

In 1888 my brother Gordon was born April 19th and he gave his life in 1918 in the first world war.

Then in 1890 Feb 11 my sister Laura was born on a very stormy night. Father had to go two miles to get a neighbor lady to assist.
And now we are slowly and surely moving
through the years from what was known as the
Idaho and now as the Bitterroot Valley. Home
was invaded by a great Bitterroot
Falls river slow. They moved very good through
for building the new land, more cheerful than
before, but any better owner could not be
more happy for him, every way he brought
out live gravel from his place from 1874
gardens were well grown very financially
as we got early fruits, nothing of hard
hired men familiar to him, but we always
had plenty of regular help.

Great farmers had small crops only about
65 acres so market was far away.

In 1888 my family's location was four miles
and he gave his life in 1918 in the great
world war.

Then in 1890 they came to Idaho and
bore on a very strong mind. Father said it wasn't
to go here onto to get a daughter lady it wasn't
In 1891 the rail road came in from Brandon as far west as Oxbow which was about three miles east of our home, and that was a great day for everyone, then followed bridges over the rivers & creeks making it so much better as it was bad crossing these streams in flood time.

The rail road followed on to Alameda in 1892 and on to Estevan in 1893.

My sister Pearl was born on March 24/1892

In the summer of 1893 we moved to a ranch eight miles west of Estevan, there had been very poor crops for two yrs before we left Alameda, so my father thought he would try something, and from a small herd he built up to have 50 head of horses & about 125 head of cattle also had 115 pigs & poultry.

The valley we settled in had a large quantity of hay & pasture, but he never tried to farm as the valley floods nearly every spring & the land on the hills is very steep.

There were no bridges over the creek that runs through the valley making it hard to cross.
In 1891 the railroad came in from Brandon as far west as Oyster Point where about three miles east of town and that was a great day for many as they followed bridges over the river and watching it go around better as it was bad running them through in flood time.

The railroad continued on to Alameda in 1892 and on to Oakland in 1893.

Samuel Pearl was born in March 24, 1892.

The summer of 1893 we moved to a ranch eight miles west of Oakland, there good for growing corn crops for two years before we left Alameda, so my father thought he would be ranching and from a small herd he built up to have 50 head of horses and about 120 head cattle also had 100 hogs & poultry.

The valley we settled on had a large quantity of hay & pasture but he soon tried to farm too the valley, finding scarcely anything growing on the hills so going along.

There were no bridges on the creek that runs through the valley reaching it back to San Pablo.
It is a terrible muddy bottom.

When my father & I first went up early in July to put up hay or build a house etc., we got very badly stuck in the middle of the creek; the horses pulled & tipped till the whippoorwill flew away, and father had to unhitch and ride one of the horses about three miles to the Missouri River, to cut an ash pole to make another one.

Well we arrived at the ranch in time for supper, then made our bed under the wagon and that night it rained quite heavy & we got good & wet, but I don't think it rained again that summer as our crops & garden at Alameda put in that spring was very poor, just giving us enough for a quiet flour & chicken feed.

My father put up a very comfy stone house hay for the stock and barn also harvested the crop that summer, and in the fall the family were moved up. My sister met me & I were left alone at the ranch house to guard the fowl from the wolves while
When my father and I went up to build a house in July
to pull up hay. We got very
badly stuck in the middle of the creek. The
house pulled, but not till the whipped tree
fell, and father tried to unstick it and ride
one of the horses about three miles to the house.
Still we arrived at the ranch in time for
supper, then on our bed under the wagon
and that night if a wind swept away
we got great comfort, but I don't think it
would have been that summer an easy
year for us. That spring was
quiet from a sickness, but
my father put up a very empty store house
stay in the ditch and farm also harvested the
crop that summer, and in the fall the
family were moved up. My mother went to
me if we were left alone at the ranch house
to gravel the floor from the window while
Father moved the family etc., and as he had not got the windows & doors on we were left rather in a jam if the wolves had been at all ferocious, but they were not—indeed even though about twenty of them sat up a sing song every night, they kept their distance, and very strange we were not the least bit afraid, as our parents had taught us not to be afraid of anything.

In 1894 Sister Mary was born on July 4th at the ranch and while I was only fourteen yrs old I gave her the first bath & thought it lots of fun.

There were only two other neighbors in the valley and as they had no children for some yrs we were not able to attend school.

But we became great riders & did most of the riding after stroke. Often riding miles without either saddle or bridle, often bringing home poisoned wolves & new dappled colts on horseback. We had quite an experience.
Mother arrived at the family, etc., and we all had well-got the windmills down on the new loft, other in a barn. The wheat had been cut and threshed, but they were not used from them. Many of them fell on a pile, and many more they kept there. 

The house was very strange we were not familiar with it. We were afraid of anything there.

In 1894, Mr. Smith came back on July 4th at the same time while I was only fourteen years old. He came from the forest path, through the hills of snow.

There were only two other settlers in the valley, and so they had no children for some years. We were not able to attend school.

But we became great friends and almost of the same age. After riding and without saddles in the hills, after bringing home several little cows and calves, we came back. We had quite an adventure.
nothing the nests of two wild goose geese getting four goslings in one nest and five in the other, my sister robbed one nest alone by herself, she rode into the marsh & fought with the goose and got the five goslings brought them home on horse back, we were successful in raising all of them, but just hunting shot them all in the hunting season, and they were all clearly marked on one wing with a large piece of bright red cotton.

In 1896 Brother Roy was born but only lived three months.

About that time our family moved to Estevan so we could attend school.

At that time Estevan was a very small village, the district was very sparsely settled, as lots of people had moved away who had taken up land earlier as we had some very dry summers & lots of crop failures.

On Feb 3rd 1898 I was married to

gutting from goulings in our nest and give

by her self, she wrote under the smell of freight

Jan 1896 Butten very was born but only lived
these months.

About that time own family moved to Zetton
so we could attend school.

At that time Zetton was a very remote
village, the district was very sparsely
settled, so the Butten's had moved
away who had taken up land earlier as
we had come very dry summers, 1878

early fall leaves.

(4th Feb 3rd 1898 I was married to
W.M. Muirhead Station Foreman & we had nearly all the village people at our wedding.

In 1899 Sister Maud was born Feb. 8th & on March 7th my first child Junie was born. They were like a pair of twins.

On Oct. 27th 1900 my son Clayton was born & still we had no Bro.

On May 2nd 1902 Sister Margaret was born & June the 2nd my second girl Pearl was born another another pair like twins.

A great many houses & buildings in Estivans were built of stone & were very good & still remain in very good repair.

The first school was stone & was used for school & church & most community entertainments concerts dances etc.

Mr Henry Yardley was Estivans first Mayor & as he & his wife were trained singers & musicians they were a great help to the town in many ways & were splendid neighbors.
Wm. Jamieson married Marion Maclean in 1899. Shortly after their marriage, they moved into the village. They had two children: James and Robert. James was born on October 27, 1900, and Robert was born on May 25, 1902.

James became a farmer and lived in the area. Robert became a teacher and taught in the local school. Both children were very intelligent and contributed significantly to the community.

The first school was built in 1899 and was used for school, church, and social events. It was a small building with a single room. Mr. Henry Yardley was the principal of the school, and he was a great teacher. He taught in many ways and was appreciated by the students.

Sadly, the school closed down in 1910 due to the lack of students.
Estevan is quite a rail road centre having the main line and three branch lines, we have quite a few industries but mostly brick or coal & a large sawmill. Due to sudden storms in Winter quite a few people were lost or frozen to death and many were badly frost bitten, but I will say I have lived here all my life & I have never been cold or hungry & I am now seventy two.

I have had eleven children four girls & seven boys, and now have thirty six Grand children & seven Great Grand children they are all alive except my youngest son who gave his life in the last great War a Warrant Officer in the Air force, all my Boys served in the Army & Air force. All my Sisters are alive and we had a re-union this last Aug., all were fairly well and enjoyed the get together.

My Sister Laura wife of Mayor Harry Nicholson lives here, and as their

My sister Laura wife of Mayor Harry
Richardson lives here, and as their
Home is right across the street from the new hotel, where most of my sisters booked rooms during the re-union. We all had our meals at the Nicholson home, fourteen of us sitting down to a long table. Besides my sisters we had two sisters who came with their mother, Sister Gertrude from Dayton, Wash., also were accompanied by Sister Isabel from Victoria, B.C. The girls drove all the way without much difficulty.

Mrs. Nicholson was ably assisted by Mrs. Campbell, a friend of the family and a daughter from nearest neighbor at Blaine, who helped. We visited many points of interest around Everett and wound up the visit with a dance & get together in the Elks hall just on by our young people and all returned to their homes tired but happy.

My Sister Pearl, Mrs. Muller & her husband have spent over thirty yrs in China she as a Dentist & she as a teacher under the
Some in flight over the streets from the
New Hotel where most of my sisters had
rooms during the reunion, we all had
our meals at the back-to-back dining room.
I was sitting down in a long table, besides
my sisters we had two ladies who came with
their brothers and girls from Gayton, Wash., also
were accompanied by ladies, several young
girls in 1946. The girls drove all the way without

Jean Richardson was also assisted by Mrs. Campbell
a friend of the family and a daughter of our
favorite neighbor at Ellensburg, Mr. Campbell.
We traveled on our own, without any
assistance and arrived up the valley with a
dance gal together in the Ellensburg hall for
our young people and all returned to
their homes tired but happy.

My sister Pearl Casso, Smith & her husband
have spent over thirty years in China as an
American. She as a teacher under the
United Church Missionary Society.

My young host living here Jack has bought the ranch taken up by my father in 1892. He farms a small portion of the land in various grain & flax, but does not break up too much as it still floods in spring. There being lots of hay etc he keeps a lot of stock. The valley land produces very good crops.

[From E.C. COOKE, Agricultural Representative, Ottawa]

[Written - Mrs. W.M. MacLeod, Edmonton]
I wrote to you old missionary brother,

my young great-harvest son Jack has bought
the ranch from us by my father in 1892
he farms a small portion of the land
in coarse grain, hay but does not break
my loam as it will produce in spring
there being lots of hay to be kept a lot
of wheat. The valley land produces very
good crops.
